er1tnypiZGBu1XJAQhC_Hw.text: Enjoyed the tasting menu with the wine pairings. This was an absolutely lovely meal. Almost everything was delicious.Only two problems: firstly, this is more of a seafood restaurant. The seafood dishes were amazing. However, both red meat dishes left alot to be desired. The beef and the venison were not good. In fact we could not eat them!Secondly, the tables are placed too close to one another. Quite uncomfortable.Service was good, maybe a bit too personable!All in all, a great dinner. The food being the best part. The 3 stars are for the food alone, not the rest of the experience. That could be improved.The gimmicky key you get at the start to claim a tiny muffin and a teabag at the end, means you end up with something to carry for the rest of the night! And nowhere near as delightful as Marcus Wareings' gorgeous chocolate truffles! So well done, but could do better!

f2X_ZTqqI06CrARg4p28EQ.text: Someone much funnier than me described the current phenomena of small plate dining as "50% of the food for 75% of the cost". I see a more worrying trend... The revival of nouvelle cuisine. Think about it. Austerity budget, mass unrest in Egypt, rising unemployment, strikes, riots and a royal wedding. We're back in 1981. With iPhones.The menu at Pollen Street Social makes the point heavily. A full two pages of small plates (or starters as I uncoothly call them) followed by 5 or 6 large dishes (or mains, keeping up?). We were told that it was entirely up to us, we could create our own menu. Maybe to go with 3-4 plates to begin, then to either take a main, or a few more small plates, or leave it there should you so wish and have a dessert or two instead. At least so decreed the man in the kitchen in the pre launch PR, but this insouciant attitude doesn't translate to the insistent restaurant staff and anyway, I really can't see anyone going to the bother of getting a table here only to pop in for a light snack. Except maybe the models flocking on the arms of their Mayfair monied rich boys, fairly joyless, overly gussied up rich people who don't really want to eat.And that brings me, finally, onto the food. A few notable exceptions aside, it was sadly also fairly joyless, overly gussied up, rich and model thin. I wanted so much to like it, but just couldn't find enough to praise. Reading some of the critics and other bloggers who have been already I may be in a minority of one, but while they're preparing the way for the pitter patter of tiny Michelin stars, I spend my life entertaining at these joints, hence the need to know the latest places and I really know what I love, and don't love, about restaurants.With the air-con off and a hotter than average London early evening outside, we went for some of the lighter plates. Despite being designed for sharing, they're not all designed to share. Fowey Oysters, hot and cold gave us only 2 crustacea, one submerged in a dashi broth, the other blended with eel and reformed as sorbet. An interesting concept, but the lukewarm mushroomy broth took more than it gave the oyster and the sorbet was a small scoop of non event, a slight and subtle briny tone overwritten by the eel. A single scallop, again with the sharing plate!, came with two denuded Jersey royals, their royal skin flayed, crisped and presented on top. The cabbage pesto alongside was interesting, big and bright. The scallop sadly was rubbery and overcooked. Crab salad was bright, sparky and everything a small portion of fresh shredded pearly white meat should be, the thinest slices of pickled daikon (a Japanese radish) gave it crunch and the look of a deconstructed Chinese dumpling and the quality of the meat shone through. The almond and crab sorbet accompanying it was a ferocious own goal, I left most of mine.The low point came with a miserly pair of emaciated red prawns, sat in a bamboo steamer on a bed of seaweed. a teapot of consomme was poured through the slats of the steamer, the 'reveal' coming after we'd eaten the two prawns - a pair of dumplings sat underneath in the rapidly chilling 'tea'. blitzed fish in odour, scrambled egg in texture, nothing to tell of in taste.The kitchen almost, almost redeemed itself with the final two dishes. The only two I would go back for from the menu we sampled, a simple onglet steak with a tiny cube of dauphinoise and a platter of smoked foie gras on thin slices of preserved apple with a raisin 'jam'. Perfectly sourced, perfectly cooked and near as damn it faultless. This was the meal I was looking for from Jason Atherton. It was clever without feeling the need to shout about it, still clearly containing the perfectionist elements and subtle twists, but these supported, surrounded and shouted the quality ingredients that deserved to be centre place, and that we should have been there to enjoy.

LjRpspp-8Swssid42w4UBA.text: Pollen Street Social offered me a comfortable mood whilst dining a Michelin starred food, which is not an easy thing to do. Moreover, the food served was great, service was always there and price was quite reasonable for three course lunch.  Their meat storage is visible from your way to the loo, which looks quite nice.I would surely go back for a tasting menu for dinner.

R30iXeqLksjhob49eBu6Mg.text: Really  hard to get a table here, or is it just for me. At last I managed to reserve a table and I do not regret the time I was waiting. A friend of mine recommended this place and said the food was fantastic, indeed it was. Try the eggs, they are great. It is an amazing how a meal so easy can be so tasty.

-lg1lhlSatvb9npULl-u7w.text: underwhelming ... over-rated ... not a good combination ... aside from being pricey, the dishes are not inventive and lack creativity... i had the 8 course tasting menu but only one or 2 dishes stood out ... the others were blah!  started with pork rinds and they were chewy and not crunchy ... the crab salad was salty ... in short i was not blown away ... i was hoping to repeat the same experience as when i dined in little social ... a sister restaurant right across but i was happier with the 3 course menu at little social ... indeed it's a hip place but for those who are looking for real good cuisine, this restaurant is forgettable ... i wouldn't recommend ...

9btD_5Le6-YM2tFsQpFtGQ.text: Went for lunch, took a lunch special offer. We arrived early, as they were just opening, so they were not quite ready but they made us welcome just the same and we sat in the bar area for a few minutes. Modern, nicely spaced tables, but every surface hard. A good range of choice on the lunch special. When it came it was simply outstanding, and very much enjoyed. Reasonable sized portions, and yes the pud was even more outstanding. The lady sommelier was freindly knowledgable and helpful, so we did well there too. But the noise. worse than school dinners. We had to shout at each other at the end. At this level of quality I don't need buzz, the food supplies it. Jason the chef was at the exit and was a delight to meet & talk to. There is a private room downstairs that could provide a better ambience..

tVH86DlVr4kRr06ZhxLimA.text: Absolutely superb food, let down by robo-service of the worst kind and lazy management.  First the context:  We took a cancellation and the three of us had a 6pm table in the bar area.  It's not the main room so we cut them some slack on ambience.  (However I wouldn't go back to sit in the bar area.  Too sterile.)The first seven minutes from sitting down were so rushed that it became comical.  Within that seven minutes (yes, we started timing it) we were (in this order) seated, given drinks menus, given main menus, served bread, asked what water we wanted, served water, asked if were ready to order our meals (while the drinks menus were still open), asked if we're ready to order wine, served house nibbles, ordered our drinks, then ordered our meals.  I GET IT THAT YOU NEED THE TABLE BACK BY 8 (although in the end YOU DIDN'T AS THE AREA REMAINED HALF FULL WELL PAST 8), but there has to be a better way to pace dinner.  Maybe the staff were so eager to get the first table going that they threw everything at us.  Either way, it was so off-putting that we went on strike.  We put our main menus down and waited until we were ready.  All the food was simply wonderful.  Drinks were great (someone said "best gin-based drink ever").  Between three people we had three drinks, one bottle of wine, two apps, three mains and two desserts.  Every dish got "This is awesome".  Well done to the kitchen.  Also well done to the serving staff.  It was all spot on.But only two stars to the house management.  That first run of the game was just amateurish.  The lighting over the table was also faulty.  Two out of the three bulbs were flickering, to the point of distraction.  I saw other bulbs in the room doing the same.  When I pointed it out the lead front of house raised the lighting, which stopped the flickering.  But then it was too bright.  So later someone lowered the lights again, which brought back the flickering.  Change your bulbs.  All of them.  Also the music in the bar is utterly useless.  It is too thin (way too much trebble) and just bad.  It was simply noise of the worst kind.  The low point was when they served the pre-dessert.  The room was so full of useless noise (not bar chatter, but rather an annoyingly stressful 80s song) that not a single one of us heard one single word that the poor waittress said.  And she was leaning in, no more than two feet from our heads.  We'd all go back for the food.  We'd never sit in the bar area.  We'll see what happens next time!  Lesson to management:  just because you're playing a more relaxed attmosphere doesn't mean you can relax.  Sweat the details.

egX4ZCdRTzd15vLR4lL6Xw.text: Fantastic food and a wonderful staff.  The drink menu is diverse and creative.    The food, especially the beef and pork, was rich in flavor and perfectly cooked.  Try to sit at the dessert bar area after dinner to watch the dessert chefs prepare wonderful post dinner treats.  We saw them use liquid nitrogen  to create chocolate ice cream bark that looked very cool and tasted amazing.

prkNuYhKvJZO4b0D4EJDZg.text: This place is amazing, it is stylish, amazing food, friendly, you are even given a gift when you leave- can not fault it and can't wait to go back. Make sure you leave room for some chocolates after your meal as they are the best I have ever tasted. My husband had the lunch deal at around £26 which for a three courser is a total bargain - as always there was no veggie options on this menu and I had to order from the normal menu - it is really starting to annoy me that places have stopped putting veggie options on their cheap menu!!!!!! Other word of advice - Vogue building is really near and who all seemed to be dining at the same time as us - felt very unfashionable!

SLbmG52HYl7SqmSRGOaObg.text: I had dinner at Pollen Street Social with two friends and their young baby (they were visiting the UK and didn't want to use the hotel's babysitting service). They were late arriving, but I felt welcome and looked after while I waited. When they did arrive, the guy was three sheets to the wind. During our meal, he kept lifting the baby onto his shoulders  she lurched dangerously amongst the designer lighting, as he seemed oblivious to the looks of frozen horror, and the forks poised midway between plate and lips of the diners around us (I truly am sorry if that was you). The reason I mention this is that the service was totally professional, all the way through. We were treated with friendly efficiency, and food and wine were both exceptional. It's the measure of a place how they deal with awkward situations and customers, and I've got no hesitation in rating this a 5 star restaurant.

WQ7M74acTbrPoo8SGFD80g.text: Sweet Jesus, Mary, and Joseph this place has good desserts.I will be upfront with you all and say this restaurant is way outside of my budget and I even ate a meal before I came as to not break the bank. Blasphemy, maybe, but this place is known for its dessert bar rather than its minuscule (although fairly delicious) meal portions. I only had soup for real sustenance and I only ordered partially not make my dining mates uncomfortable as I slowly enter a drunken stupor without anything to nibble on to cut the alcohol. It was a tomato gazpacho with crab meat, delectable though it was it was about the size of a newly born hamster (or maybe a small beach crab would be a better comparison in this case) and cost £10.As we came to Pollen Street Social for my friend's birthday, it was of the utmost importance that we take full advantage of the dessert bar, which on this fine evening was manned by a chef named Joe. Joe was not only easy on the eyes with a good sense of humour, but that boy prepared two excellent desserts for us. While he ignored my suggestion to shove a candle in the tiramisu or sing Happy Birthday (double Blasphemy), he was incredibly thorough in explaining how all of this nonsense was made (as I half listen, half gorge orgasmically). The two desserts (a deconstructed tiramisu and a sort of pile of candied fruit and fruit/veg/herb sorbets) were accompanied by hot chocolate and three different sorbets to sample. Just thinking about it makes me want to eat a chocolate bar while running around the block (in feeble attempts to cancel out the weight I am gaining just thinking about our dessert while satiating my now drooling sweet tooth).ANYway, I would say Pollen Street is worth the £ for the desserts. The rest of the food is obviously good as well, but not as exciting or inventive.

9JQ2TbAiuyxIEEZGZ3rHcg.text: Best place in London!!!! Great food, great wine selection. Taste and culinary heaven on earth. What else is there to say! You definitely need to book ahead though.

l4PxvD0pSVv5NZWLWw460w.text: We came here for lunch as part of our anniversary celebration. Warm, modern decor and friendly staff. They even have special stools for your purse :)While lunch isn't cheap, it is a good value for the quality of food. We were presented with a box of amuses, which included the best pork rind ever - fried in house, light and airy with a dusting of seaweed, yum! I got the poached egg, toast, and mushrooms to start while hubby had the terrine. Both were delicious and beautiful to look at (a consistent theme here - everything that came out looked gorgeous!). We moved on to a perfectly cooked cod fillet with squid ink vinaigrette and braised beef cheek. Desserts were amazing! Aside from what we ordered, they presented us with a special cake square for our anniversary that looked like a ring box with edible silver on top. Dark chocolate ganache... mmm. Then finally finished with little almond cakes that were still warm. We left so relaxed and happy with our meal!

kln7LXOowqd6edgA6RXo8g.text: One of the best experiences in London. Flawless execution and service. The star of the show is their PBJ.

TFuPedkZcT2Frd5lqocD6Q.text: It's ALL about the Scrabster... Seriously, the most amazing reduction you're likely to find this year.in fact everything was extraordinary and the service attentive but not all up in your grille. and as you wait for your dessert they will bring you an intermezzo that will bring you to your knees.first five star rating i've given in a very long time.go. eat. be happy.

vvdP8Cb7xX7RtojCSYllDw.text: It seems I had a slightly better experience than GrumblingGourmet with my visit to Pollen Street Social. In short though, I can't give it more than 3 stars due to the service, price and that the dishes were a bit hit and miss. First the service. We arrived at 5.30 and were told they were booked out for later in the evening but there was a table from 6 to 7.45. Not wanting to wait 30 minutes and then sit down we asked if we could grab a table right away. No problems with that. The thing they forgot to mention though was that the kitchen didn't open until 6.00 leaving us to pass the time with some (fairly expensive) bar snacks and cocktails. I wasn't too fond of my cocktail I have to say but the chipirones (small squid) were excellent as a starter with the heat of the green chilli they came with. Overall the service seemed sketchy and confused throughout the evening. When you leave you trade the key you get when you arrive for a small bag of breakfast stuff, but they forgot to give us the key. All minor issues that added up to a bad experience with the service. The food was quite good, at least mine was. The cauliflower & squid with clear roasted squid juice and truffle was tasty and light with a nice added element of the crunchy truffle bits on top. The heirloom tomato salad, tomato vanilla gazpacho, tomato sorbet and creamed burrata was excellent as well, great for such a hot day. Very refreshing. The mains were good and bad. I had the rack of Cotswold lamb, braised belly, sheep's milk curd was perfectly cooked and had some interesting combinations of flavours. The West Country ox cheek with tongue & sirloin, carrots, caper & raisin purée and horseradish mash on the other hand was really dull. The only redeeming feature was the horseradish mash which was great. The tiramisu for the dessert was a bit heavy for me and more like just ice cream with some chocolate crumble to go with it. It was OK but no more than that. If they sort the service and the dishes out I would consider coming back again. Funny enough regarding the dishes Jason Atherton was a couple of tables over with his family trying new ones out and commented on one as "a 5". Hopefully that won't go on the menu.

K5cHJCdVeIvVZV1b5Jp2aw.text: Pollen Street Social has kind of a dumb name, but so does Dick Swett and he was a Congressman!Amazing restaurant -- my favorite in London at the moment.Poached egg with smoked hake and garlic puree starter was something special.  My main, a braised beef cheek, was less memorable but still fantastic.  My wife had the vegetarian full-english as a starter which was delicious, and perfect gnocchi as a main.Drinks were excellent; my vaguely American sounding drink came with a little bowl of popcorn.  It was my wife's birthday and they gave her a gift when we left -- a lovely chocolate cake.  Everyone is ultra friendly, and the place has a great vibe.Going again this week if that says anything!

Ts09nk-GMC1fdoPJx1HveA.text: Ended up in the neighborhood early for a meeting and decided to pop in to inquire about a table for lunch. To my surprise they had a table in the bar. We ordered set menu (excellent value) of pork terrine and roast pork belly. Terrine tete de porc was outstanding, as was the pork belly. Good wine selection though being on way to a meeting, we didn't explore it. Hardly a place for a very cheap lunch, but certainly good value.

qBrdQwAvDdP3S0AELvK9_w.text: classy, classy.my friend and i came for dinner last night and were not disappointed.  she is always afraid that places get hyped up and the restaurant turns out to be a letdown, but PSS lived up to the hype!when you arrive, the hostess hands you a key which you are told to hand back as you leave the restaurant.  i started out w/ the champagne breakfast cocktail, which was mighty strong.to start, we were brought a salt cod brandade and an appley dip and a small bowl of olives.  we shared the crab salad and parsley soup apps.  the soup was delicious w/ the truffled hen egg on top.for our mains, we shared the halibut and the beef.  the beef was amazing and came w/ sirloin, ox cheek, and beef tongue.  on the side, they gave us horseradish mashed potatoes.  the portions are actually pretty generous here, and we were full, but who could resist dessert?there were 2 seats available at the dessert bar, so we perched there.  we were given a scoop of passion fruit sorbet and lime and cream cheese sorbet to start and cleanse our palates.  we then got the tiramisu and the pb&j, and both were FAB.  we scarfed down the desserts as if we hadn't just had huge dinners.  on our way out, we handed back the keys and were presented w/ a bag each of breakfast for the next day!  the bag came w/ a bag of tea and 2 mini muffins.  what a nice touch!  this is definitely a place to come for a special occasion...or for no particular occasion at all!

f9wHXNV5TiWtI0xyDSKmhA.text: PSS is one of those rare places that not only lives up to expectations - it smashes them. I don't often find that a restaurant that I've looked forward to going to for ages really matches up to the utopian version in my head. The service is lacklustre, the food bland, or perhaps the wines didn't complement the meal. But not so with PSS as Jason Athernon's newest effort prides itself on sleek elegant form, a novel approach to drinks, and an open and well-crafted view towards the balance of tastes and textures in each dish. Sure, it wasn't perfect (and we'll get to that later), but would I go back? Damn straight!I initially thought I'd write a full fledged review, however it's passing 4 pages in MSWord so perhaps a summary would be more appropriate. Anyone interested in a detailed run down and evaluation - please drop me a line.The food is excellent both in taste and presentation. The standout out of the array of starters was the squid and cauliflower. I will admit that upon reading the description, I thought "nice but kinda boring". I could not have been more wrong. While not as visually bold and appealing as the other dishes, each shade of white and cream represented a flavour bomb waiting to land on your tongueThe squid was tender and paired well with the creamy cauliflower. Hidden bits of puffed rice added a surprise crunch that was pleasing to both the palate and the ear. Overall, an exceptionally well designed and executed dish.For the mains, the tasting of ox (cheek, tongue, and sirloin) had the fullest flavours and felt the most satisfying. I will note that the Spanish prawn rice accompanying the red mullet was also exceptional. The rice, served in a mini-sauce pan, had a spicy smoky flavour that was incredible. A cross between a risotto and a paella, it slipped over the tongue in a red creamy sauce and seduced your senses.  I'd happily eat the rice as a main course on its own.The sommelier is very friendly and helpful with choosing a wine. Plus points for actually listening and participating in a debate about wines and then selecting one in our price range without trying to shamelessly upsell. The cocktails were fantastic and demonstrated the high level of skill of the barstaff while showcasing their creativity.Dessert was an experience all to itself. If you can, leave your table for the glamour of the dessert bar where you can watch the lovely ladies of all that is sweet prepare desserts in front of you. It makes it uber hard to choose which dessert to have and thus it's better to go in a group where you can order several and share. My top pick was the PBJ which had the freshest and most delicious flavours of peanut butter and raspberry jam I've ever had (including in a PBJ!). Plus, the peanut meringue is made with liquid nitrogen which just knocks it up a notch.Slight minor gripes would be the bread guy not knowing much about the bread (beyond "white" or "brown") and the bill taking another 15 minutes to arrive after we asked for it but nothing to really mar the evening.

aWJvMDaP50hsKLrv83eIKA.text: I cannot praise the Social highly enough. Beautiful seasonal food prepared by one of the finest chefs in London. The lunch time menu is faultless both in quality and price- at 22.50 for 2 courses and 25 for 3, who could say no? I chose the two course set lunch menu and had:Ham hock with coco beans, squid and picallili. Followed by a generous portion of Yorkshire partridge with plum jam and kale.

HUhHRhTX0y7Qa_g9gaq3DA.text: I'm dishing out 5 stars for an overall fantastic experience, start to finish. Very friendly staff, very knowledgeable bartenders and waiters, who really tend to you.We arrived on a busy night, still felt genuinely special.The food then, well I can agree with what someone else wrote about what's on the menu. Nothing stood out for me when I first looked but we'd heard that the desserts were great and I was feeling like a steak, so Rib-Eye it was. Not expectiv much from a still fairly pricy (30GBP) piece of meat - BOY did they blow me away.Best piece of meat I've had in a long while and I just tried out Palms and Goodman. Fellow diners had Oxcheek which just fell apart from tenderness with a potato pure to die for.We were then given the opportunity to sit by the dessert bar and talk to the chefs there while they prepare and being able to form our own opinions on what to have. They were all fantastic. Just right amount of "molecular" cooking with a pure explosion of tastes (who would have thought that black-olive ice cream or basil sorbet would rock your socks off)So yes, we did splash out and this place is not a cheap eat (which I tend to love) but it was just worth it. Because this to me was much more than dinner it was a full on gastronomical and guest service (which many people get wrong) experience.

cbntR58uWXy_HVL7P6F0Yw.text: This review is based only from my visit to the bar... yet I wanted to mark it as I was very impressed by what I received here, a positive lead onto what reminds me more of the New York cocktail scene.You : choose a spirit of choice, and state any desire for another particular flavour (sweet/ sour/ bitter/ herby etc).Bartender : makes you a personalised drink, whilst providing mild entertainment around the edges. Not the interfering-with-your-night-type, just the keeping-you-a-little-extra-company style. And much appreciated.Thank you boys, I'll be back for more and maybe even some food...

WVVIn9R41uP3ZLpbLiNyOA.text: This meal was perfection. Came here for a wonderful dinner with coworkers when I was in London recently. The entire dining experience was really delightful. The burrata starter and the cornish turbot were both delicious. We had a bunch of other starters and they kept sending out different desserts....I loved everything. The entire meal was out of this world!

idBHs19ix9ToDfLFXgsE9Q.text: I had not expected to like this meal so much. I did not want this meal to haunt my dreams. Now I'm going to spend a ton of money to return to London to eat at this restaurant.Where to begin - quiet, hidden location; large modern dining room; service as good as any you'll find; a menu where you want to try every. single. thing.; enough extra courses to fill you up on their own; quality of ingredients as good as California.Let's get one thing out of the way; London is crazy expensive for Americans. OK, so recalibrate your cost expectations. Within that context, PSS is an upper-end place but not ridiculous.No time now to detail every course, but of the four of us (starters, mains, desserts, plus amuse and other freebies) there wasn't a single miss. Everything was spot-on and just amazing. Large portions too. :)For London fine dining, I can't imagine anything better.

DdjmFrVm0r2953mbZUcrmA.text: We went there for the 6-course tasting menu. The restaurant was quite huge. Service was so-so.  Small dishes were great. Main entree did not taste delicate. They focused more on presentation and lacked delicacy. We were able to see the kitchen and saw something gross. Both the main chef and second chef were doing this. They would taste the dish with a spoon and then use the same spoon without disinfecting and washing. Often they would dip the spoon in a tiny water container (not running water) and then reuse the same spoon. Yuck! They were pretty diligent about inspecting the food visually or by touch (for temperature of bread) before the plate went out to customers. Dessert was pretty good. It was fun to watch the pastry chef use liquid Nitrogen for most desserts. Oh, they also miscalculated our bill. Bad sign for a pricey restaurant. Will not go back.

Djz7rU0IK4R22VIH8EJwlA.text: Perfection at its finest!  What can I say? This is definitely one of the best meals we ever ate. From its understated element decor to the exceptional service from the get go, we knew we were somewhere special.   The chef started us with a mushroom broth reminiscent of our dining years ago at Alain Chappel in France. Then we had course after course of the most interesting and the most delicious favors one could imagine.  The sommelier is very knowledgable and professional and made excellent pairings with our meals. And the wait staff could not be better.  They are excellently trained and catered to our every need.   We wanted from nothing and never to ask for anything.   From the first bite to the last, we were in heaven.   The best! Compliments also to the front desk who were very kind. I am only sorry that I live in Los Angeles and will have to wait until my next trip to London to have this experience again.

upXrQ62NKrFOxxmgXJMLnA.text: What more needs to be said than that after dinner, my daughter said that "was the best meal I ever had."  Great service, great presentation, great food. All was terrific but I highly recommend the squid, the duck and the venison.  The tea preparation was really cool.

iwu6siRslY-tmfYT-Zvezg.text: I'm torn. I really wanted to like Pollen Street Social. I was really excited about it! After one of our good friends mentioned that he wanted to go with us to a nice meal in London with his wife, PSS was the very first place I wanted to go try!So the other half and I arrive early to have some drinks. The cocktail menu looked amazing, and every single cocktail we had was interesting and unique, and my favorite by far was the Shiso Lovely (Asian influenced with Kaffir lime leaves? sign me up!), but we also had The Professor, Rum and Coke (a specialty drink, not just your standard R&C), The Rumbullion, and the Vintage Vesper of which they were all great. They all supplied us with fresh salted nuts whenever we ran out, so it was a fun time to be had before dinner.For dinner, we had the tasting menu. It looked interesting, and we were all excited about it. We asked for help to choose wines to pair, and that's when things started to go downhill. The sommelier seemed clueless. She stood there barely suggesting things, and the ones she did were very inexpensive. Not that expensive wines need to be suggested, but it would be nice to have a variety. We selected a white and a red, and I was a bit dubious about the white selection (Chateau Ste. Michelle in Oregon? It's a fairly big winery, and not something I would consider. That being said, it wasn't the same label as usual, and was in partnership with someone else, and the wine was reasonable). The other half decided to put the wine selection into his own hands after that, and he managed to do a better selection of wines than we were told about during the wine selection.Now for the food, honestly, of the eight courses we had, which were all interesting conceptually, the only one that really stood out as spectacular (for me) was the scallop sashimi. The Japanese flavors really came through, and the horseradish snow was very nice. The next two that were really good were the desserts. Both were pretty in your face with flavor. Other courses were lacking something. The turbot needed quite a bit of seasoning, it was mostly bland. The duck was a bit tough and chewy. The oyster ice cream was overly fishy/salty tasting. The full English breakfast was interesting, but hard to get all the flavors together at first, and the tomato really overpowered a lot of the taste (for me). The crab salad had some sort of granata on top which really wasn't pleasant with the rest of the meal. Most of the courses seemed like they were trying to hard to have an interesting take on something, or an interesting combination of textures, but failed in the flavor combination (unfortunately a problem of presentation over flavor I think). We had a bit of an issue at the end with the petit fours. First, a small cake (which was amazing), then some candies and some mini macarons. There were three different flavors, and the other half and I wanted to try all of them. The server refused. The other half pushed, and she said she'd have to talk to the manager. She came back and said that they would charge extra for them. I wanted to drop it then, but the other half asked how much, and finally they came back and said we could have them for free. I've never had a Michelin star restaurant give us such a hard time over a few extra petit fours. To be honest, the macarons weren't really that great to have been given such a hard time over.So would I go back? Depends. I would definitely go back for cocktails, as they were the best part of the night. I might even try the dessert bar, as we were seated near it and the stuff coming from there smelled great (and the two desserts on the tasting menu were great as well). I wouldn't go back for the food, it wasn't interesting or special enough to be given another go. There are other fine dining places that I'd want to eat the food at before coming back to PSS.

xQMkJOlOEPtV6bbnsAkFKw.text: Suffering from jet lag and starving, I googled (sorry yelp was too tired to really think) "best restaurant london" and up came pollen street social. Even better it was just a few blocks from my hotel. So off I go. I get there at 5 min before 12 and they open for lunch at 12. The place is completely empty. I ask for a table for one and the hostess responds with "just one?" as though somehow one was not enough. She then informs that they don't have any tables available. Did I mention the entire place is empty?! When I bring that somewhat obvious point up, she offers to seat me at the bar. Ok fine seat me at the bar, I'm tired and hungry. She seats me at the worst possible spot at the bar right over the sink. Since I'm only 5' 3" my feet are dangling off the stool. I am so tired I know I am just going to slide right off halfway through my meal. So I get up and go back to the hostess and say if they can't seat me at one of the literally dozens of empty tables I am just going to leave and find somewhere else to go. She goes back to get the Manager to speak to me. The manager informs that they can seat at one of the tables in the bar area not the main dining room as long as I won't be more than an hour since they have many lunch reservations. Lovely. Fine I agree I won't take more than an hour to eat my lunch. So now I am seated at the worst possible table in the bar area with the wait station right behind my head.What kind of serious restaurant treats customers this way? Ok so now for the food. The food was actually quite good. Lunch is a prix fixe menu for about 25 pounds which is a very decent price for decent food in London. My starter was something with smoked haddock, a poached egg, and a green sauce. It was exquisite. My entree was something fish. It was also perfectly executed but not very memorable. The vegetarian menu on their website was not available for lunch. Fortunately I think of fish as swimming vegetables but there were no vegetarian options on the lunch menu. Something to keep in mind if you're vegetarian. All in all the food was great but the staff is way to uptight for the "deformalized dining" this restaurant claims to offer. The food is on par with any good restaurant in San Francisco but I think overall London restaurants have a lot to learn about customers service and not taking themselves so seriously...

MIskWGZuiIVUra7XLc6NZw.text: I think 4.5 would have been the perfect rating.  We did a set menu here and its exactly what you'd expect.  Great food, great service and great wine.  The dishes we had were middle of the fairway but the quality was just fantastic.

NBDmcrTahXVcmY20hy0oRQ.text: London does high end dining incredibly well an Pollen Street Social met all of my expectations. I visited on a cold and wet Monday lunch the week before Xmas and the dining room was absolutely buzzing.  Must have been all that Xmas cheer in the air. This is a big restaurant. The spacious dining room upstairs is large but feels spacious with a small pre-dining bar area and a sneaky view into the kitchen and a large team of busy busy chefs.  Downstairs is a lux private room which would be perfect for a special occasion or corporate event, a very versatile space. We choose the excellent value 3 cars Xmas set lunch which at £35 was a bargain.  The menu was gorgeously seasonal and quite complex.  All choices sounded gorgeous but I went for the clever entree eggy full English breakfast, a gorgeous lamb shoulder main course and Thai flavours dessert which was fresh, pretty and light.  The wine list is huge but the friendly sommeliers are on hand to guide you should you need any assistance with the many many options.  There are wine to suit most budgets as well which is great.  I would have liked to see a few more beers available - just the meantime lager, pale ale and IPA were on offer which is a shame for a British restaurant living large on its local produce when there are so many incredible ales produced right here in Britain. We we pleasantly surprised with between course treats - 3 canapés to start, a zingy pre-dessert cleanser and maroons with coffee.  I love surprises and these are the very best kind! Rather than being stuffy this was an exciting and engaging dining experience.  Many elements of the food were interactive and the busy, festive dining room made it clear that everyone there was having a great time.  All in all this was an entirely pleasant way to pass a rainy afternoon.  It's not cheap but it is a great example of the Brits doing a fabulous job at world class restaurants.  Jason Atherton and his team should be justifiably proud.

photos.caption: Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Mum, lamb shoulder with Malbec.  So good!

UAHvAJer6cFbY-qS9-SH9Q.text: We went for a special London Restaurant Festival event. Full disclosure David Gandy was present, which may or may not influence this review!We started things off with cocktails at the bar. We got chatting to Monica, one of the bartenders, and she talked to us about her inspiration for the cocktail list. We loved the Pisco and the Professor cocktail, pisco, fino sherry, lime and flat leaf parsley, inspired by Monica's travels in Peru. The cocktail list changes regularly and we are very tempted to come back and work our way through more of Monica's creations!The appetizer was yellowfin tuna tataki with cucumber salad and avocado and ponzu dressing. Ponzu is Japanese citrus based sauce (yes I googled for you!) and the appetizer was lovely, light and refreshing. Just what you want when you know heavier course are around the corner.We started with a  quail, broad bean, pancetta and sauce diable. The quail was cooked perfectly and a summery dish.Next course was rack of Romney Marsh lamb with braised shoulder shepherd's pie. It felt like we'd moved from summer to winter, the shepherd's pie was hearty and indulgent, I don't even want to think about how much butter probably went into the mash but it tasted divine. The lamb chops were ruby pink and delicious, but the fat was flabby and chewy. I think either crisp the fat or remove it, my preference would always be to crisp it, fat=flavour. Sadly, I had to leave mine on the plate as it was inedible.Finally dessert, white chocolate mousse with salted caramel and shards of caramel hazelnuts. I have to say I don't really like the trend towards salty/ bitter desserts, for me those flavours can be present but they need be balanced with sweetness, otherwise what's the point? You might as well have another plate of savoury! I was surprised by this dessert because in the past I've found white chocolate to be sickly sweet, but here I think they were so intent on keeping that in check that the balance went the other way and it just wasn't much fun to eat.I much preferred the petit fours which were fun, playful and more crucially sweet! Rapsberry and almond financiers, and yuzu and blackberry mini cones dipped in white chocolate were delicate little mouthfuls with which to finish.Just a quick mention about service, we were tucked behind a little corner and we felt a bit forgotten about. On a couple of occasions we asked for more bread or water and it either never came or arrived very much later. However as I mentioned David Gandy was present and it was a full house, so maybe service was not representative of what it normally is.

OnijpfvSkD3EdmoiZN2BBA.text: Items Selected:Sugar and Salt Smoked NutsParmesan Cheese Foam, Mushroom Crumbs, Mushroom Consomee / Goat Cheese Churros with Truffle Honey / Black Pudding Croquette with sauce gribiche / Black Garlic Cookie with taramosalata Baguette, Whole Wheat Roll, Sesame Brioche, Tomato and Basil Biscuit - Farmhouse Butter and BrandadeBent on Revenge - Grapefruit Juice, Espresso, Palm Sugar Syrup, Elderflower Cordial, Fever Tree TonicChilled Pea Soup, Citrus Crème Fraiche, Peas, GambasHaslet Terrine with Mrs. Brown's Black Pudding, Mustard Seed Dressing, Carrot, Toasted SourdoughPine smoked Quail "Brunch," Cereals, Toast, Tea - Box smoked Quail, Brioche Toast with Liver Mousse, Quail Broth, Crispy Quail Egg over Crispy Grains and MushroomsBraised Lake District Lamb Neck - Jersey Royals, Nocoise Flavors, Black OlivesRoasted Squab Pigeon & its Offal, Honey Spiced Beetroot, Date and Black Tea Puree, Pickled PearsYogurt Foam, Strawberry Soup, Cucumber GranitaStrawberry and Calamansi Eton MessGoat's Milk Rice Pudding, goat cheese ice cream, oat and milk crumble, honeycombWhite Chocolate Coated Strawberry Ice Cream Cone / Raspberry Financier / Frozen Chocolate Peanut Butter MoussePostulated by many to be London's next recipient of a second Michelin Star it was to Jason Atherton's Pollen Street Social that I turned for lunch after touring The Tower of London and although duly impressed by the famous crown jewels it is still my experience at the sixty-seat restaurant that shines brightest in my memories of that day.  Decidedly more 'American' in design than the majority of London's top tables, with a front-side lounge largely secluded from the proper main room, it was in fact in the bar that I began when I mistakenly arrived 20 minutes too early and yet picking at mixed nuts as I sipped a complex mocktail while chatting with its creator I immediately felt at ease, not a bit of pomp or pageantry to be found.  Eventually led to my seat when the restaurant officially opened and soon greeted by a server sporting both menus and a complimentary second Bent on Revenge it would not be long before difficult decisions were presented and with inquiries of portions plus presentation addressed a six-part order was crafted, though what followed in the ensuing two-and-a-half hours would prove to be much, much more.  Undersold by Atherton as "casual fine dining" considering both the quality and creativity displayed in each bite from the very beginning it was in a quartet of culturally diverse inspirations that the eating began and proceeding next to bread service far more inspired than that of revered local restaurants I couldn't help but overindulge, the eagerly replenished salt-cod spread something I regularly seek out menus and would have gladly paid surcharge for.  Continuing on to things more substantial after a gift of pea soup from the daily prix-fixe the influence of Atherton's time under Ramsay became quite apparent in both bright colors as well as complex herbal aromatics presented on the plate and with the tableside presentation of smoked quail stealing the show from beautifully gamey housemade terrine in round one a bird again shined for course two, the charred organ meats of a pigeon aggressively matched by soft flesh and just enough sweetness to keep it all in check.  At this point assenting to finish the meal at Pollen Street's signature pastry counter where a team of two tended to a half-dozen or so creative desserts it was once again to a gift that I arrived and with the light soup harkening the very essence of summer the plates that followed would prove equally inspired, the eton mess' crunch giving way to a fruity cloud of flavor while the stick-a-spoon-up-straight pot of rice pudding was carefully boiled before my eyes and served to be ladled atop a savory sundae par excellence.

7P7Nm9dB7aV_inyYqbNIgQ.text: Elegant atmosphere, creative menu and sophisticated cocktails, the Pollen Street Social was a happy surprise. Perfectly located on a quiet side street off Regent Street makes it easy to escape the busy pace just around the corner and literally escape to an oasis. Attentive service and just an all around pleasant experience. Am already planning on going back.

UH-GaWgR4J8Owg6uxyNc3Q.text: Our evening was really fun and the food was good. I struggled a bit between a 3 and a 4 star. The atmosphere was good but it was absolutely BOILING in the main dining room - they had fans but they didn't make much of a difference. The amuse Bouche at both the beginning of the meal and the end were INCREDIBLE! Churros with a honey dipping sauce, delicious chorizo fritter and a flat black olive bite were incredible! I asked for the signature/ most popular dish on the menu and straight away was told the quail for a starter and turbot for a main. The quail was interesting really fun presentation and pretty good. The turbot was really forgettable which was disappointing for a signature dish. With all of the great London spots I'm not sure I would go back.

G8Xnpm6xKgn1HncZI5odfQ.text: Had an I believe beef tartare while visiting London. This place definitely deserves the Michelin star. I'd fly back to London just to eat here every day.

37_DgDFaaTde1tloUL_T9Q.text: Kicked off with cocktails at the bar. Adored the Plum Japonaise: vodka, umeshu, lemo, cedarwood and bitters. Monica talked to us about her inspiration for the cocktail list.Starter was quail, broad bean, pancetta and sauce diable. The quail was cooked to perfection and this felt like summer on a plate.Next course was rack of Romney Marsh lamb with braised shoulder shepherd's pie.The lamb chops were ruby pink and delicious, but the fat was flabby and chewy.Finally dessert, white chocolate mousse with salted caramel and shards of caramel hazelnuts. They tried too hard to keep the saltiness and sweetness balance and so was just a bit lifeless. It just wasn't much fun to eat.Just a quick mention about service, we were tucked behind a little corner and we felt a bit forgotten about. On a couple of occasions we asked for more bread or water and it either never came or arrived very much later.

MEhvFCkOYBmVbQTPYCNw1w.text: Hands down, the best place for fine dining in London. One of the best things about pollen street social is the indulgent in-between-course treats that they offer FOC. The goat cheese churros with honey dip, one of these treats was simply amazing. My main course was the sea bass, which really wasn't too spectacular. I would recommend ordering red meat dishes such as the venison, which is more substantial and hearty for exactly the same price. I was impressed with the chocolate marquise, mousse and praline which we ordered for dessert. However, the goat's cheese rice pudding was just overwhelming, DO NOT get that unless you seriously love goat's cheese! Overall, this place is definitely a winner and unlike other fine dining restaurants, you won't leave hungry or broke.

YbP19BuPap4rPZmeodZYEg.text: Beautiful space, excellent cocktails, sublime food, and near perfect service!From head sommelier Laure's impressive and effortless wine knowledge to our waiter's superb attention to detail from across the dining room, my first experience here will be one of many. Seafood and game were creatively imagined, expertly prepared, and beautifully plated. Bravo!

tQqCHJvn3L0HYhnHZSxA3g.text: Oooh was that lunch delicious! I went to Pollen Street Social on a group trip to London and was delighted when I saw the restaurant chosen for that lunch. The Yelp reviews were great and I must say I very soon knew I would be another one to add a 5-stars review to the place.Let's be brief:- Design and setting are perfect. We were seated in a small salon downstairs, absolutely perfect, chic, cute and quiet. A dream.- How much food can you eat? We had pre-starters, lots of bread, starter, main course, dessert and pre-dessert! All was absolutely delicious and I won't spoil your pleasure and tell you about the dishes here, but they were really worth it and both traditionnal and very original. Loved it all!- Service was a dream too. Very attentive staff, a French speaker waitress to translate what strange words such as "halibut" or "venison" might mean, and a special choise of dishes for vegetarians at the table. Perfect.All in all, a definite 5 stars and I definitely want to go back to PSS and spend more time there! PS: I didn't pay for the meal so I had no idea about the price rate, but I checked on the website and I think it's quite good value for money! pollenstreetsocial.com/m…--- En français : un établissement que je recommande chaudement ! La cuisine était délicieuse, le service parfait, les vins très bons et les quantités impressionnantes ! J'y étais en voyage de groupe et n'ai donc pas payé ni vu les prix, donc je ne peux pas juger le rapport qualité-prix, mais pour la qualité seule, c'est un sans faute ! J'y retournerai ! PS : Après vérification ce n'est pas donné mais plutôt bon rapport qualité-prix ! pollenstreetsocial.com/m…

gsw-tCSG5pb1jB2zZSCQZA.text: One of the best dining experiences ever! First, the food was amazing! We loved everything we ate. The flavors were so interesting and the presentation was beautiful. The cocktails were unbelievable -- really creative, really fantastic. The service was some of the best service I have every had. The staff was really knowledgable and so warm and friendly. They even let us go into the kitchen and meet the chef. BEST dining experience EVER!

ZbC04BM4fN5vnCdGrzAXLg.text: This place has style, ambiance, knowledgeable and friendly staff, excellent food, and even better wine and cocktails.  I went there a few months ago and I can't seem to remember my exact dish, but I do remember loving the food, but overall the experience is what stuck out (and my overwhelming jealousy of all the fabulous artwork!) Hopefully I will go back soon and introduce more people to the excellent addition to the London scene.Plus the 'breakfast bag' you get at the end of the meal is a cute, if random, perk.

photos.caption: Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Red sea cocktail, fog included!

y6_BytjdgaGZjmagnPvkzQ.text: Oh My!I was lucky enough to walk into this restaurant without a booking (although I hear it can be quite difficult to get in) and could not have been happier!The staff were so attentive and helpful I actually thought it just opened and they wanted feedback, it turns out they simply take their job seriously and are keen to make it the best possible experience. This had me already giving them two thumbs up. Each dish is like a mini piece of art, a delicious delicious piece of yummy art. If you get the chance have your dessert at the 'dessert bar' as you can watch some very talented people craft what has to be one of the best dishes in London.

4SV3wW151tAto3SE_fo7Ig.text: Drinks:-The wine list is a 30-page exceptional read with favourtism given to the wines of France.  -Most glasses run from 8-15, and bottles can go up to 2500-Wine pairings can be arranged to go with the menu offerings, which was the route my partner decided to go.  All of the pairings were appropriate and thoroughly enjoyed.-Bar Manager Gareth Evans has created a remarkably creative and innovative cocktail menu that changes often. I took a quick peak and decided that I absolutely could not resist. It was going to be a boozy night.- I had a crazy hard time deciding because literally everything struck my eye. Each drink featured whimsical presentations with unique and exotic ingredients including sweet pickle juice, toast and jam (still not sure what that is), beetroot rose, and "British eccentricity" (you will see what I mean below).Day of the Dead : (13.50)-Blew my mind. Yes that's a skull, and yes I ate it. The drink arrived with an antique style perfume atomizer, which the server used to spritz with chocolate mist. The result was an incredibly balanced drink with wicked sex appeal.Great British Cobbler #2 (13.50)-If you like big fruit flavours, this is a must try. It was sweet, tangy and beautifully aromatic, and I loved its British cheeky charm.Jimmy's Giant Apricot :(13.50)Again, a really well balanced drink, this one being the least sweet of the bunch. I liked the combination of the floral apricot with the tangy pineapple and the bitter plum. Fab.Food:-Chef and owner Jason Atherton was the first British chef to complete a stage at Spain's elBulli restaurant.-They offer an a la carte menu as well as a 8-course (85) and 6-course (60) tasting menu that can be paired with wines if requested-Not surprising considering chef Atherton's training at elBulli, there is certainly a significant molecular gastronomy influence in all of the dishes-We opted for the 6 course meal and decided to select a different main course so we could sample more (the only option we were given in that evening's menu)Snacks: Pork Crackling; Parmesan Biscuit with Tomato and Anchovy; Caraway Cracker with Whipped Smoked RicottaServed in a big hollowed out book, these bites were a lovely start. My favourite was the caraway with the smoky whipped ricotta.Tartare of Irish Fallow Deer, Smoked Beetroot, Wild Leaves, Berry Pearls, Sourdough CrispsMy favourite savoury dish of the night. The gaminess of the venison went beautifully with the sweet beetroots, tangy berry pearls and the caraway-scented crisps.Roasted Dorset Monkfish, Cauliflower, Dehydrated Grapes, Apple & Curry, Spiced CaramelMy least favourite dish of the night. While I loved the cauliflower with the aromatic curry and fruit flavorus, I didn't think it worked well with the fish. I also wasn't a huge fan of the monkfish's texture, which I found a little rubbery for me. Roasted Squab Pigeon, Salt Baked Red Cabbage, Beetroot Stained Onions, Yakitori Pigeon OffalI loved the natural sweetness that the beets imparted on the caramelized onion, while the squab was perfectly seasoned and surprisingly tender.  Lake District Rack of Lamb, Braised Shoulder, Fregula in Basil, Olive Powder, Artichoke & Smoked Tomato ChutneyThis to me was the better of the two mains. The lamb was flawlessly prepared, and the shoulder was cooked to a meltingly tender consistency. The star, however, was the herb scented fregula which offered a delicate little pop and brightened up the whole dish.Mini Ice Cream : Mango, Yogurt and Coconut SorbetWhere they get these baby cones I don't know but I would certainly love to find out. The combination of the sweet mango, the creamy coconut and the tangy yogurt was incredibly refreshing and fun.Cantaloupe Melon & Camomile Tea Sorbet, Yogurt, Sudachi LimeSimilar flavour profile to the palate cleanser that came before it, but this featured an wickedly fragrant lime front and centre. The combination of the sorbet with the yogurt yielded a texture similar to a silky foam that simply melted on the tongue in a state of utter bliss. "Thai Flavours" : Peanut Cream, Green Apple & Yuzu Puree, Compressed Celery, Frozen Praline My favourite dish of the night. It tasted like a sweet version of the classic pad thai with a wonderful balance of salty peanut and fresh tart apple yuzu puree. I loved the texture of the compressed celery which lacked any stringy or fibrous quality, and the little bits of praline were addictive.Petit Fours: Strawberry Jams Financier, White Chocolate Ginger Lemon Chocolates, Macarons (Green Tea, Chocolate Ganache, Japanese Peach)A lovely way to finish our meal alongside some cappuccinos. My favourite little bite were the white chocolates as their sweetness were nicely balanced by the sour lemon. That sweet tangy flavour kind of reminded me of those yogurt candy covered raisins that I am completely and utterly in love with

esd0u1P6uT98vmjnm8QVjA.text: One of the things that I liked most about this place is that Jason Atherton was actually cooking in the kitchen. He doesn't just have his name to the place, he was actually in the kitchen. I'm not sure if this is an every day occurrence but it was nice to see him doing his thing in the open kitchen.We had the tasting menu which I thought was delicious. The things that stood out to me were the frozen horseradish and scallops (seems to be everywhere at the moment), the all day breakfast in an egg shell, then turbot with the cauliflower cheese puree, and the beef with the marrow crumb. All that was needed to leave me satisfied was a Highlander cocktail complete with Scottish weather cloud (lavender whisky on dry ice) which was probably the best whisky based cocktail I've ever had.Overall, the vibe was smart but modern (no white tablecloths and compulsory jackets here); the food and drinks were delicious; the service was attentive but not overbearing (very important for me), the lighting was intimate but not dark, and the open kitchen was a bonus. Highly recommended!

b2LbFzezJ4YfSJ8UALv4OA.text: One of the finest meals we've ever had, in a restaurant that managed to feel both casual yet special at the same time. We still dream of the goat's milk rice pudding.

J1mwwLezslEH_dbuj9y7Dw.text: How can I say....  Jason Atherton is my favorite chef in London.... Location is great - a bit of back alley and private...  the setting is perfect, nice open space...  Food is great, especially consdering the price.  What Jason does so well is take a group of ingredients and make an amzing dish at a good quality price...  he is really one of the kind...What is not so amazing is....  service.  I think there are two reasons....  in order to achieve this excellent value, something has to give... and I think it is reflected in quality of staffs.  They are all very young, not very experienced and they have little understanding in what defines class in services....  Hostesses at an entrance is bit cold as well....When it just opened, I think it had a bit more class and better services...  think it has been too popular...  shame to see such a great venue not striving to be the best....At least food quality is still there...  it is a bit embarrassing to have so many young, unprofessional working and serving dishes. Must avoid for business occasions for sure.

apHBg2LalPyMmrmRy5Q7xA.text: Top class. Great service and QUALITY !An attention to detail that is worth 2 Michelin stars, they will get them sooner or later. Thank you for making our lunch a really good time.Ideal for a friends lunch, or business without pretentious intent.Food = 9/10Lots of amuse-bouche and quality mignardises that tops the experience, really.

t1RBREH5wZlv0eebH4gDng.text: Food was nice. A bit to much small amuses. Skip truffle oil in starter pls. Cote de boeuf very good. Apple dessert good acidity in ice cream.  Be carefull with the wine suggestions of the sommelier $$$.

ylTEnQvYvSI2KLz3gfg5QA.text: Lovely place with amazing wine list and great food served with care and attention. We took a delicious tartare as starter, with truffle slices that proved to be an amazing eating experience. Lamb rack was super delicious with a Sheppard pie on the side that was mind blowing. Really adored this place. Price is commensurate to the experience.

nPqeNwi4X_5bbAHtszdIxg.text: I loved having a special birthday meal here with my partner. The food is gorgeous.. the service is excellent... and it has a lovely chilled atmosphere. We had cote de boeuf and it came with carrots, beans and Mac n cheese. It was very filling and we couldn't finish it. We also had starters and they were both delicious. This place isn't priced like Nandos, and probably not at the price point for most to pop out to on a whim (also needs to be booked in advance) but it was, in our opinion, very reasonably priced. It was better than most of the steakhouses I've been to in London, if not all. My only minor criticism is the use of space in the restaurant. We lucky didn't have anyone sitting next to us until we were about to leave, but I'll put it like this: I could smell her perfume above the aroma of food, too close for me.

JQmaaQGMY3Q_Ag9BzvPvAQ.text: Pollen Street Social may be somewhat of a mainstay on London's fine dining circuit, and we found it generally deserves the accolades. From the moment you step into the refined space, there is a sense of confident luxe. The dining room may be streamlined and posh, though it is not sedate, particularly as the night progresses. Jason Atherton's menu leans toward familiar flavor profiles, but his approach is not at all banal. Cuisine is executed with precision and finesse. The wine list contains an interesting array of options, with some highly rated gems. Service is top notch and professional. Overall, we really enjoyed our experience and think it warrants the Michelin star. Look forward to trying Chef Atherton's NYC outpost - The Clocktower.Atmosphere- Sleek and modern; a minimalist luxe that still felt approachable.- Some white table cloth formality, but the approach is not stale.- Pleasant din; neither noisy or too quiet.FoodJason Atherton's cuisine is clean, and a pleasant blend of classic flavor profiles with a refreshed viewpoint. It would be nice to have some additional vegetarian and meat courses on offer for the first course. The weak point in our experience was clearly the dessert course, as the Brogdale Pear lacked both heft and interest. We enjoyed:- Raw Orkney Sea Scallop (pickled kohlrabi, nashi pear, black olive, jalapeño granité - £22): Even as a non-seafood eater, I enjoyed this dish. It was very delicate and refreshing, though still flavorful; the granité was especially interesting. Nice, clean dish to start with.- Whole Roasted Goosnargh Duck (braised swede, quince, pesto served with a salad of duck leg in Moroccan spices - £79 for two): Loved it! Deeply flavorful, and the salad was interesting in and of itself. Wish the fat had been rendered slightly more; but near perfect.- Brogdale Pear (goat's milk ice cream, honey & bee pollen - £13): Least enjoyable dish; it came as a tiny slice of pear. Flavors were basic. Needs more than the bee pollen gimmick.BeverageWine list is extensive at Pollen Street Social, though some areas could use additional options across a variety of price ranges (e.g. Burgundy). There is a nicely curated list of by-the-glass options. We selected the 2013 Domaine des Lises (Maxime Graillot) Cornas (£135) from Rhône to enjoy with our duck. While the wine had pleasant aromas, it was rather tightly wound and tannic. Would have really appreciated if the wine had been decanted to soften things up; surprised about this oversight, as it sat in the bottle the entire evening. With dessert, the 1996 Château Coutet Sauternes (£15) is a nice option.Service- Very hospitable and attentive, making good recommendations when asked.- Not overly mechanical or impersonal.- Failed to decant wine, which was unfortunate as it could have benefited from such.- 12.5% service charge automatically included.

Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Brogdale Pear (goats milk ice cream, honey & bee pollen - 13)
Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Whole Roasted Goosnargh Duck (braised swede, quince, pesto served with a salad of duck leg in Moroccan spices - 79 for two)

8n6GmhE6dTb4RuoYfz0mww.text: I've been to Pollen Street Social three times over the space of a few years, and it's not what it was, unfortunately.The first times I went with groups of friends, we had a lovely time; great food at a reasonable price (considering the location, quality and service). The food was inventive, the service was warm and smooth, and I knew I wanted to come back the next time we were in town.When I came more recently, it was a very different restaurant; prices have risen considerably, and the food is more conservative, less fun. Service was very spotty; some staff were warm and welcoming, others perfunctory and even officious. It took a very long time to get our first courses, although it did pick up after a while.I can't help but think that this is due in part to the clientele; it seems that with fame, a different set of people have become interested in Atherton's restaurants. That's a pity, as this was one of my favourite restaurants in London.

B1WjtQK1-gYMmQ9kzNMdmw.text: My first dining experience abroad and I must say, they did not disappoint.  We had a reservation so we were seated immediately, my two friends and I.  We started with the Canape' which was an assortment of little amuse bouche.  1st time ever having such an experience but I welcomed it.  I tried everything they put on the table, which was A LOT.  Mushroom Tea which was served hot in a small tea cup.  A Peach Sorbet which was smooth and delightful.  A bread served with a cheesy like butter, they offered various types of bread: white, wheat, etc.  My main course (pictured) was a lamb w/ shepherds pie, the lamb was cook perfectly but I expected a bit more portion wise.  The shephard's pie was warm, smooth to taste and very delicious.  For dessert a Pistachio Souffle which I didn't enjoy but I'm glad I tried it.  The pistachio was prominent, which made the souffle green, there wasn't much flavor and the ice cream melted too quickly which made it soggy.  They announced and explained every dish they brought to the table.  Before the main course, the waiter came and used this little crumb snatcher to prepare the linen for the next course.  My friend went to the bathroom and put her napkin on the table, they prominently folded it while she was gone.  The manager or maybe a person from the bar staff even went so far as to run out and grab an ingredient they were missing to make my friend a particular drink they were offering.  That was impeccably nice!  I had a Free Ginger Beer which was quite strong due to the ginger which I welcomed but I was looking more for a ginger ale .  There were several people involved in serving us and they were all polite, helpful and great at their jobs.

photos.caption: Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Assortment of desserts offered after we paid the bill.

Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom

GNfSLbzWSecFIuTb1Uotag.text: One of my favorite restaurant in London!Food was very innovative and service was attentive!I love all the appetizers we ordered and they are not just delicious but unique combination of ingredients (see photos). For entree we got the whole roasted duck to share, it reminds me of the whole roasted chicken in NoMad restaurant in New York (the presentation was almost identical). Their duck for sure lost though, I have to say this one was mediocre, a bit disappointed.We got the Eton Mess for dessert, it was super delicious. Layers from the crispy meringue to mousse inside. LOVE IT.Cocktails were good too but not amazing.Overall a great experience!

MRWQT7G4UdLE-FzKdCJ5_g.text: An unassuming restaurant tucked away in a London side street. This place is worth the visit. The service is impeccable and the hosts are extremely knowledgeable about what is on your plate.

G_M3AERMSIbmhvZLTriMqw.text: Food is subpar. Service is over the top. Concept is good. Paid £100 each but it worth it. Not coming back here again. We went for the tasting menu. To be honest the food tasted like aeroplane food. Although it was creative, nothing really had flavour. It was either too creamy, no plain, too fishy and just downright average. They must have come to our table over 20 times. They brought the salt and pepper, then the bread alone, then the butter alone, then the water plate alone, then the water, then they swiped the crumbs off the table before and after every dish. I mean, ffs people, can we actually enjoy ourselves without you there or have a conversation without being interrupted?

fQ-9lbv8EcLns0-s21b3lg.text: A dining experience like no other.    The service is excellent.   The food is beyond fantastic.   Take a moment and watch the chef and staff work plating the dishes.  Chef Atherton saw me watching and invited me into the kitchen for a tour of the kitchen.   Very nice fellow/artist hard at work spinning dishes that are out of this world.    Best meal by far of our entire trip from the cocktails down to dessert.  This is a restaurant that should not be missed.   Do yourself a favor and make an effort to get a table.    You won't regret it.

photos.caption: Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. A view of the main dining area.

RUnWQLL0PHV_quSjB16BSA.text: I have been wanting to go here for a while now and decided to give it a go when a special occasion came up.  We arrived without a reservation for lunch and took a seat at the bar.  We had a great afternoon, eating and drinking, but I would have to admit that my high expectations weren't met by the meal we had.  We started with a really refreshing cocktail.  I don't remember what it was called but it had beetroot juice and ginger beer in it.  We got served the book of little snacks that everyone has mentioned.   This was a non-memorable diversion.  Everything tasted fine but it was hardly an explosion of flavour in your mouth. As a starter, he had the crab salad and I had the scallop carpaccio.  I only had one bite of the crab salad but it was tasty and light.  The scallop carpaccio was just ok.  The scallops, while fresh, tasted a bit heavy and felt gluey in the mouth.   The normal sweetness of raw scallops didn't quite go with the kohlrabi.  I really struggled with this flavour pairing.  Additionally, I'm still confused as to the purpose of the frozen grapefruit.  I actually was more impressed with the fact that someone had taken the time to separate all the little grapefruit pips than anything else!  For our mains, he had the duck and I had the lamb.  Both were good but given the £30+ price tag, I was expecting OMG AMAZING.  It was not all that.  The duck was beautifully presented with the purple beetroot really making the dish stand out.  The rack of lamb came as two perfectly cooked pieces and the shoulder was shredded and formed into a little breaded disk topped with the fregola.  It was all very tasty and you could not fault the cooking but everything lacked the little bit of extra oomph I was expecting.  Given all this, the standout was really the service.  The bartenders were chatty and perfectly attentive.  It was a low key dining experience and it was totally enjoyable.  We didn't want to spend a lot on wine, only about £40.  I was slightly embarrassed that they sent the sommelier over but we told him our price range and what we wanted and he not only proposed an excellent French red but it came in at only £29.  There was no upselling which was a really nice surprise!     So overall, it was a good experience, made all that much better because of the service.  The food was all well prepared but there was nothing about it that made it stand out.

cnIGeI5Dmv307qijOpwSTQ.text: Lovely modern french restaurant. First proper meal in London for me on my first visit. Came on the recommendation of colleagues, and was not disappointed. Had a 3-course set lunch, but with all the additional amuse bouche and petit fours, might as well have been an 8-course meal! Service is polite and pleasant. They have a full service bar and an excellent selection of spirits and cocktails. Ordered a gin martini, and was very pleased that the bartender stirred the cocktail by default. The martini was excellent, and served in a mini wineglass instead of that silly upside down lampshade they call a martini glass. My lunch partner had his cider served in a most righteous pewter mug. Food is excellent. Flavours are well calibrated and not overwhelmingly heavy on the palate, which Asians like me are more sensitive to. Had ham hock terrine starter - a nice mix of saltiness and funk. Amuse bouche comprised canapes - smoked salmon on bread, a dill cream cheese thing, and a cream cheese raspberry mini tart which was divine. This was followed by a mushroom tea with cream. Rich mushroom stock, and silky cream - tasty. Had the pheasant, which was roasted and served on a bed of fennel and endive, and an orange compote. The pheasant was well roasted - not too gamey and tender. The orange compote set off the flavour of the meat very well. Dessert was a selection of ice creams and sorbets - ranging from a rich vanilla ice cream, to a strangely complex peach grapefruit thing, as well as a surprisingly lovely lavender and lime. My favourite was the pear sorbet. Rounding off the meal was a petit fours of apple crumble and chocolate ganache, and a scotch caramel flavoured with Bowmore 15. A very epic lunch, a great way to start off my London experience. I could barely have dinner! Will try to visit again before i go.Update: Visited again with my missus before leaving London. In the interim, I read up on Pollen and learnt it was a Michelin-starred establishment. So I arrived with slightly higher expectations, and was not disappointed. My missus had the set lunch, and I went a la carte. Waitress suggested the special, which was a truffle linguine in parmesan foam, which I opted for. Had a seafood soup for starter, which the waitress suggested I have as a second, so as not to overwhelm my palate before the truffle linguine. Very thoughtful! The meal was excellent, and we were given the option of having dessert at the dessert bar, which we gladly did. Watching the patissiers at work was most delightful. The highlight of our meal though, was having the opportunity to meet and greet the proprietor and head chef, Jason Atherton, whom we saw from afar in the kitchen, busy helping to finish the dishes before service. He was kind enough to help my missus out of her chair, and I took the opportunity to gush about the food. He was most obliging, and spent a few minutes chatting with us about his new tapas restaurant in Singapore, Esquina. And he was very kind to oblige me with a photograph. A very class act, and I'll be sure to visit his restaurants here in Singapore... Once my wallet recovers from this very pricey, but very satisfying meal.Another update: it seems that Jason Atherton has divested himself of his partnership with Unlisted Collection, and is no longer involved with Pollen at Gardens by the Bay, Esquina and the like.

photos.caption: Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Had the good fortune of meeting Jason Atherton, who kindly obliged me with a photo and a friendly chat.
Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom. Lunch at Pollen Street Social is an epic affair. Make reservations early, and set aside 2 hours for a 3 course lunch.

R5WUvkFf3qlfBY-AZFXeYQ.text: Came here for their very affordable lunch prix fixe (3 courses, £29.50), and was blown away by the food and the service! Although lunch officially stopped at 2.30, I managed to get a reservation at 2.30, and they were nice enough to hold it until 2.45 since I was rushing there from outside London. Throughout the meal, the service was very unhurried, formal and very attentive. Loved it.Food-wise, it was fantastic, and we especially loved the amuse bouches that came with the meal. It was a lot of fun, and we appreciated how the staff took the time to explain every component of the dishes. We had:Starters- Chiled pea soup, citrus creme fraiche, peas & gambas- Cumbrian beef tartare, sourdough crouton, goat's curd, truffle dressing & dried vinegarMains- Roasted Cornish cod, English crayfish, summer vegetables, Scottish girolles- Roasted breast & confit leg of Goosnargh chicken, truffle braised celery, apple, endive & summer squashDesserts- White chocolate mousse, caramel hazelnuts, salt caramel ice cream- Strawberry & calamansi "Eton mess"Highly highly recommend the cod - it was fresh and amazingly tender. The chicken breast was very moist and flavorful as well. We had mushroom tea and cheese churros with truffle honey to start, and I loved them. They also came on a pretty tiered stand which lent itself very nicely to photos. Pre-dessert was also awesome, in the form of yogurt and strawberries with a glass straw. My favorite part was the frozen chocolate banana ganache, which was very light and not overly sweet. Highly highly recommend :)(Sidenote: We saw many of the other diners receiving a little bag of chocolates (?) when they left, but we weren't offered one when we left :( )
