EVO4IweRewn-vcNrDJT5SA.text: We went to pollen street social for New Years eve.  The food was pretty good, but after a week eating whatever and wherever we wanted, it was by no means out of this world.  The reason for my poor review is the service.  After a really disappointing experience, I sent the below email to the Pollen group and to the restaurant manager.  I opted to contact them directly rather than complaining on yelp, but..... It was sent 3 weeks ago, and I never heard anything back form them.  A restaurant group with this reputation should really pay more attention to service, and at least give the courtesy of a response.  email I sent:To whom it may concern,I wanted to write you let you know about my husband's and my experience at your restaurant on New Year's Eve so that other guests do not have a similar experience. My husband and I stayed at the Rosewood hotel and they suggested that for us to contact you directly.We were excited to try Pollen Street Social for New Years eve dinner after hearing great things from our friends in London and the concierge at the Rosewood.  We arrived early and waited at the bar and were finally seated nearly 30 minutes after our reservation... I get it... New Years Eve is crazy. Once seated, our dinner was off to a fantastic start.  The food was good, and service attentive.  It was once we got close to midnight that things fell apart.  A server came by at 11:30 PM  asking if we would like champagne at midnight, and we said that we would love a glass to toast the new year. It was the last we saw of anyone for well over 45 minutes.  Midnight came and went and our wine and water glasses were empty. We watched as the staff celebrated and we were just waiting at our table.  At that point we were thirsty, tired and ready to leave.  I'm sure you can understand that it is unnerving to see the staff loitering and having fun while we're patiently waiting for service - water and our last course for 45 min.I know that the 31st is a big night for restaurants, but it is also for your patrons.  We were thoroughly disappointed with the experience-- especially because Atherton's restaurants are so hyped around London and that we paid nearly $400 US Dollars for dinner. Our experience was well below the price we paid for dinner.I hope that you will share with your staff as a way to improve operations.

9vIPlijhQc8BCw0b3ZOVCw.text: Good food, good service, nice ambience - but not cheap.We had the tasting menu, which comprised of quite good modern fare with a touch of classical French - but the fun part was when they moved us to the pastry bar to watch the pastry chefs make our desserts.Overall, it was worth the price but don't expect much (if any) change from £300 for two.

x0zohR9sufBPF0M3JTjs2Q.text: I've been to PSS about 6 or 7 times. Progressively over the last few years the food has  dropped in standard and possibly creativity. PSS still serves great cocktails and desserts though. Sommeliers have always been great here and no matter what the food the wine has always been spot on. Service is good cannot fault it in the slightest.

NObiPCRytO7PBJu2nO2ynw.text: I managed to get reservation here for lunch while in London. I could only get a table for 1 at noon (table for 2 would have been at 2:45pm instead). This was weird because my table was actually for 2.. They just took away the extra seat.So i opted for their 2-course lunch set, very decently priced at £26. I got a soft egg starter and a lamb neck main. Aside of your order, they also would offer you white/brown bread & butter and three canapes, which was uniquely presented inside a box.Food came very timely. The soft egg starter was delicious and the lamb neck was so so tender. Overall it was a very good experience especially for the price! It's definitely one of the cheaper dining option in london, at least for the lunch set.

Photo of Pollen Street Social - London, United Kingdom

rWpKEjuw5STsai-zej_T2w.text: My friend and I dined at Pollen Street Social last night, eager to add a Michelin star to our collection. If I could do it over again, I would advise skipping the starters and the desserts, because the standout feature of the restaurant is their outstanding presentation and execution of the free amuse bouches and petit fours. For the amuse bouche, we had a mushroom and cream soup that was utterly divine. This was served in a teapot. The rest came on a high tea type of tray with churros and truffle honey, a cornbread type thing, a little black square which I can't even describe, and a green sauce vaguely resembling pesto (my best guess is that it's a parsley or alternative herb type of pesto). The latter went well with the cheese garlic bread they had on offer, which was very more-ish. For starters, I ordered the squid "cooked in cauliflower, roasted squid juice, ink rice & sea herbs). I thought it would be like grilled squid with a small spoonful of rice, but instead it was like risotto, and the squid was cut into pieces the size of rice grains. Innovative, but not entirely my type of thing. My friend got the salad of British garden vegetables, and that was just a few large leaves of lettuce, with hardly any dressing. She didn't enjoy it very much, and only nibbled on a few leaves.For mains, I got the lamb, which came with a braised neck and merguez sausage. It was well presented, with the usual sauce in a separate pitcher, but overall it was just an ok fine dining dish, and not worth the £38 they are charging at Pollen Street Social. My friend got the suckling pig, which is apparently their other most popular dish along with the lamb, and it was also just ok. What I also felt compromised the experience was the fact that it took over half an hour for the mains to come out, after we had already had two courses. When I asked the staff to check on the dishes, they came back and told me 1-2 minutes, and it turned out to be another 5-10. Then after we finished the mains, the staff came back and asked if they could interest us in some cheese, I thought this was going to be complementary to make up for the delay. It wasn't, so when they wheeled over the selection of 12 cheeses, we politely declined. They really made no apology for the service failure. This annoyed me so much that I genuinely considering removing the optional service charge.After we also declined to order dessert, had paid the bill, and were ready to leave, they came out with the petit fours. First, there was a grape mousse that was so light, we initially thought it tasted like strawberry and pineapple. There were then a number of other items: a dark chocolate mousse, an innovative variant of apple ice cream served in a tiny wafer cone, and a madeleine. By that point, we'd already eaten far too much, so only had a bite of each. Overall, I think the amuse bouches and the petit fours are a nice touch, but I struggle to see much value in this restaurant. The wine list was similarly outrageously expensive (it was difficult to find a bottle under £40), and all mains are over £30. Everyone around us was drinking bottled water so we did too, and it comes at £4 a bottle. It's billed as a bistro with deformalized fine dining, but I found it quite the opposite and rather formal, more appropriate for a business dinner. You won't have a bad meal, but there are plenty of other places in London that can offer the same for much less.

caXJ1_6F3EKaSMJgLaBsJA.text: This is one of the best restaurants in the world.The cooking is as good as it gets.Casual yet smart the staff is super attentive without being intrusive and totally on top of every detail.The courses are expensive but worth it.Very accomodating to every whim and especially to vegetarians.The sommelier Lucasz is incredible and has wine knowledge beyond almost all in his field.He is a jewel.The six of us had so many dishes that it was beyond comprehensive and each and every one of us had an incredibly memorable meal.The Pig three ways was the best pork dish ever!Run don't walk here and you will go back time after time.Superb!

B5Whaqs2U9dMN0n4Rdu3Cg.text: We had tried Little Social a bit ago and we were excited to try Pollen Street Social. Expectations were higher and were exceeded!Various amuse bouche were served and the first was in a cute wooden book box. Presentation here for all dishes was special and added a bit of excitement. The quail first course came in a wooden smoker box. When they opened the drawer of this box, the smoke whirled out and the scents wafted into the air...noms!I had never tried cardamom with fish and just absolutely loved it! We were not huge fans of the goat's milk dessert. The goat's cheese ice cream was very overwhelmingly and took over the flavors of the dish.Hay smoked quail "brunch", cereals, toast and teaLine caught Devon squid cooked in cauliflower, roasted squid juices, ink rice & sea herbsRoasted Cornish turbot, bulgur wheat, turnip,pear & cardamom puréeRoasted Creedy Carver Devon duck, honey & spiced turnip, beetroots, pickled pearGoat's milk rice pudding, goat's cheese ice cream, oat & milk crumb, honeycomb "PBJ" Peanut parfait, cherry yuzu sorbet, nitro peanut

ulvHUixTGzOJUeAoA7HRhw.text: I ate at the bar a few weeks ago and was not disappointed.  The service was excellent and the variety of interludes and amuse bouche lived up to a restaurant of this reputationI started with the Yellow Crocodile, a drink with the glass coated in powdered sugar which you were supposed to lick as you drank each sip.  It was a very complex cocktail and amazingly prepared though I would probably go in a different direction on another visit.  I had the rabbit for a main and it was excellent but the highlight was the Eton Mess for dessert.     Everything was delicious and Id recommend it for foodies everywhere.

8iaoo_src4gbZAUqqA865A.text: There is a musical genre that involves taking the finest melodies, employing a large number of classically trained musicians to play these melodies to an arrangement that has been planned by enormously talented arrangers. The purpose of this music is that it is then played in the background to dinner parties or dates. It is not supposed to intrude on the conversation.In case you are in some doubt the music I am speaking of is Easy Listening.Now superficially fine dinning can look very similar to Easy listening music. Finest melodies = best ingredients, army of classically trained staff ... Check and finally the planned arrangements by enormously talented people ... Well some chefs seem pretty impressive to me.The key differences are that for the price of a fixed price lunch at a Michelin starred restaurant most people can buy more easy listening albums than any two people will need in four lifetimes. After all the point of easy listening is that it isn't supposed to be the centre of attention and to my mind fine dinning really is supposed to be the centre of attention.Pollen street social has decided that there is a place in the market for a fine dinning restaurant where the food should be as much like Easy listening music as possible.It is all beautifully presented, beautifully made and there may even have been some clever touches (ice cream made from creamed corn) but at no point is any of it exciting. Nice to eat yes exciting NO.The wine recommended to us also pretty much fit the bill and none of them can have been considered cheap (I actually had more interesting wine at the 28-50 at the corner for a lot less).Now I recognise there is a place in the world of music for easy listening and I recognise that there is a place for expensive restaurants in the west end that serve easy to eat food and easy to drink wine at very high prices. If those are the things you want from your night out then Pollen street social may be the place for you.Personally I want my food to be exciting and my wine to be interesting and maybe I and my friends will spend less time talking about our jobs, our families and being sophisticated and spend our evening being blown away by someone else's talent in what can be done with food and just how good their wine cellar is. Oh and I still go to gigs that are too loud to talk during.
